title: How to Maintain Appliances to Conserve Energy

steps.headline: Set the thermostat no higher than 68 degrees Fahrenheit (20 degrees Celsius) in the winter and no lower than 78 degrees Fahrenheit (26 degrees Celsius) in the summer.
Clean air conditioner and furnace filters frequently and replace them regularly according to the manufacturer's recommendations, or sooner if needed.
Turn the thermostat on your water heater down to 120 degrees Fahrenheit (49 degrees Celsius).
Enclose your water heater in an insulated water heater blanket.
Place dirty dishes directly into the dishwasher and run it only when it's full.
Turn off the stove and/or oven a few minutes before the recipe suggests, using the residual heat to finish cooking the food.
Cook small meals in a toaster oven instead of a regular oven.
steps.description: Warm meals in the microwave rather than the oven when possible.

steps.headline: Use glass or ceramic baking dishes in the oven and lower the temperature by 25 degrees.
steps.description: The food will cook in the same amount of time.

steps.headline: Avoid opening the oven door when the oven is in use unless absolutely necessary.
Limit the number of times you open the refrigerator and freezer doors.
steps.description: Add or return multiple items at the same time whenever possible.

steps.headline: Place pots and pans on the correct sized burners on the stove.
steps.description: Center them on the burner or flame.

steps.headline: Allow dishes to air dry in the dishwasher.Turn off heated drying.
steps.description: Open the door after the cycle, if necessary.

steps.headline: Clean stove burners, the oven, and the microwave regularly for more efficient energy use.
Keep door seals tight and coils cleaned on the stove/oven and refrigerator.
steps.description: Use a mild soap to clean the door seals every 6 months to keep them from drying, cracking, or splitting. Blow, vacuum, or gently brush the dust off refrigerator coils.

steps.headline: Keep refrigerators with external condensers in the rear at least 2 to 3 inches (5 to 8 cm) from the wall to allow better air circulation around the condenser coils.
If your refrigerator or freezer is not frost-free, defrost it periodically.
Wash clothes in cold or warm water.
steps.description: Whenever possible, wash full loads, using the shortest cycle and lowest water level possible based on the size of the load.

steps.headline: Clean the lint filter in the clothes dryer after every use.
steps.description: Clean the dryer vent every six months to one year. A clogged dryer vent not only limits efficiency but also poses a fire risk.

steps.headline: Dry clothes in batches of 2 or more loads while the dryer is still warm.
Turn off any unnecessary lights when leaving a room, even if only for a short period of time.
Unplug appliances or electronic equipment that are not used frequently.
steps.description: Consider plugging the items into a surge protector and turning off the power to all items from the switch on the surge protector.

steps.headline: Manage outdoor lighting using a timer or a fixture with dawn-to-dust or motion sensor capabilities.

text: Whole House System Conservation Tips Set the thermostat no higher than 68 degrees Fahrenheit (20 degrees Celsius) in the winter and no lower than 78 degrees Fahrenheit (26 degrees Celsius) in the summer.  Clean air conditioner and furnace filters frequently and replace them regularly according to the manufacturer's recommendations, or sooner if needed.  Turn the thermostat on your water heater down to 120 degrees Fahrenheit (49 degrees Celsius).  Enclose your water heater in an insulated water heater blanket.  Kitchen Conservation Tips Place dirty dishes directly into the dishwasher and run it only when it's full.  Turn off the stove and/or oven a few minutes before the recipe suggests, using the residual heat to finish cooking the food.  Cook small meals in a toaster oven instead of a regular oven. Warm meals in the microwave rather than the oven when possible. Use glass or ceramic baking dishes in the oven and lower the temperature by 25 degrees. The food will cook in the same amount of time. Avoid opening the oven door when the oven is in use unless absolutely necessary.  Limit the number of times you open the refrigerator and freezer doors. Add or return multiple items at the same time whenever possible. Place pots and pans on the correct sized burners on the stove. Center them on the burner or flame. Allow dishes to air dry in the dishwasher.Turn off heated drying. Open the door after the cycle, if necessary. Clean stove burners, the oven, and the microwave regularly for more efficient energy use.  Keep door seals tight and coils cleaned on the stove/oven and refrigerator. Use a mild soap to clean the door seals every 6 months to keep them from drying, cracking, or splitting. Blow, vacuum, or gently brush the dust off refrigerator coils. Keep refrigerators with external condensers in the rear at least 2 to 3 inches (5 to 8 cm) from the wall to allow better air circulation around the condenser coils.  If your refrigerator or freezer is not frost-free, defrost it periodically.  Laundry Conservation Tips Wash clothes in cold or warm water. Whenever possible, wash full loads, using the shortest cycle and lowest water level possible based on the size of the load. Clean the lint filter in the clothes dryer after every use. Clean the dryer vent every six months to one year. A clogged dryer vent not only limits efficiency but also poses a fire risk. Dry clothes in batches of 2 or more loads while the dryer is still warm.  Other Conservation Tips Turn off any unnecessary lights when leaving a room, even if only for a short period of time.  Unplug appliances or electronic equipment that are not used frequently. Consider plugging the items into a surge protector and turning off the power to all items from the switch on the surge protector. Manage outdoor lighting using a timer or a fixture with dawn-to-dust or motion sensor capabilities.
